posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: I want to get the current alliance, and I want to do this without using a runnable/lambda that is called every time I want to know the alliance, or putting it in periodic of a subsystem. Is there any other place in the code boot sequence that is good to get the current alliance reliably? Including in the simulator?

posts.name: jdao
posts.cooked: How about periodically setting a variable that is updated in disabledPeriodic() ?

posts.name: Noah Stricker
posts.cooked: DriverStation.getAlliance() will return the current alliance whenever it is called, regaurdless of if in sim. However if there is no current alliance (for example the driverstation is not yet connected to the robot) than there will be no alliance and DriverStation.getAlliance().get() will error out. To ensure this doesn’t happen you should first check DriverStation.getAlliance().isPresent() before calling Alliance#get()

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Hmm, for me in the sim, DriverStation.getAlliance() is always empty, even after I set the state to “disabled” or “teleop”.

posts.name: Noah Stricker
posts.cooked: Well the alliance is not related to the enabled/disabled state of the robot. I would recommend checking the option in vs code (or unchecking, I can’t remember) when simulating to use the actual driver station interface, instead of using the one in the sim.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
It is related to the “connected” status of the robot. When the robot changes from “disconnected” to disabled or teleop, the getAlliance() remains empty, at least in the sim.

Also isn’t the whole point of these changes to the sim to simulate the real behavior of the real DS and FMS ?

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: This was the solution for me, I guess there’s no avoiding calling it periodically.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: That should work in sim. What version of WPILib are you running? There was a fix in 2024.3.1 related to this.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: I got it now, when I called it via periodic. I am running 2024.3.1.
